articleText:
Title: Gas to groceries: Has Trump kept his promise to tackle rising prices?

URL Source: https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/ckgkl25734go?at_medium=RSS&at_campaign=rss

Published Time: 2025-11-06T00:51:45.610Z

Markdown Content:
11 hours ago

Tom Edgington BBC Verify, Washington DC

![Image 1: Getty Images Donald Trump in a suit gesturing towards grocery items](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/f5e3/live/b05d3a60-ba82-11f0-98a7-ed301ba6f979.png.webp)Getty Images

President Donald Trump was swept to power for a second time on the back of a central campaign promise to tackle inflation.

The steep rise in the cost of living was top of voters' minds and Trump blamed President Joe Biden.

He also made sweeping promises to bring down prices for Americans "starting on day one".

One year on from his victory, BBC Verify revisits some of the president's claims.

Groceries
---------

"When I win, I will immediately bring prices down, starting on Day One," Trump declared at an August 2024 news conference surrounded by packaged foods, milk, meats and eggs.

Official data - which includes a four-month period when Biden was still president - [shows grocery prices rose by 2.7% in the 12 months to September 2025](https://www.bls.gov/news.release/pdf/cpi.pdf), with some items seeing significantly sharper increases:

*   Coffee: 18.9%
*   Ground beef (minced beef): 12.9%
*   Bananas: 6.9%

Since Trump took office in January, the data also shows that apart from one recorded fall in April, [grocery prices have risen each month](https://data.bls.gov/dataViewer/view/timeseries/CUUR0000SAF11).

"The president of the United States has very little control over the price of food, especially in the short term," food economics expert Professor David Ortega told BBC Verify.

Trump's tariffs are driving up prices of certain foods, he said - a third of coffee consumed in the US comes from Brazil and therefore has a 50% tariff.

Trump's illegal immigration crackdown may also have had an impact, Ortega adds, especially in farming where as many as 40% of workers are estimated to be undocumented, which is close to a million people.

"As you know, farmers and companies have to raise wages in order to attract more labour. But trying to quantify those impacts in terms of price increase is almost impossible at the moment."

Diane Swonk, the chief economist for KPMG, believes tariff and immigration policy changes have contributed to higher costs.

"There's no question that those shifts are now starting to show up as inflation pressures," she said.

But she adds that other factors, including weather events, have contributed.

"On coffee you had climate issues for a very bad growing season and that was exacerbated by a tariff on Brazil and also Colombia," she said.

![Image 2: Getty Images A woman examines a carton of eggs in a grocery store](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/49d9/live/303263e0-ba89-11f0-ba75-093eca1ac29b.jpg.webp)Getty Images

A White House official told BBC Verify President Trump did not control weather patterns in South America and coffee prices hikes were a global phenomenon.

[Data that tracks the cost of coffee](https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/PCOFFOTMUSDM) shows prices have risen globally, peaking in February, but are now falling.

The same official said the president was addressing rising beef prices by temporarily increasing imports.

While grocery prices are up overall, not every item has become more expensive.

When Trump succeeded Biden in January, [the price of a dozen large eggs was $4.93](https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/APU0000708111) (£3.79), rising to a record high of $6.23 (£4.78) in March following bird flu outbreaks.

Since then prices have fallen to $3.49 (£2.68) a dozen.

"President Trump's supply-side policies are taming Joe Biden's inflation crisis," White House Spokesman Kush Desai said.

Other items that have fallen in price over the past 12 months include: [butter and margarine (-2%), ice cream (-0.7%) and frozen vegetables (-0.7%)](https://www.bls.gov/news.release/pdf/cpi.pdf).

Electricity
-----------

During his campaign, Trump pledged to cut electricity bills sharply.

"Under my administration we will be slashing energy and electricity prices by half within 12 months, at a maximum 18 months," he told a rally in August 2024.

Since he became president, prices have risen.

The latest figures show average residential electricity rates reached [17.62 cents per kWh (kilowatt hour) in August 2025](https://www.eia.gov/electricity/data/browser/#/topic/7?agg=1,0&geo=vvvvvvvvvvvvo&endsec=8&freq=M&start=200101&ctype=linechart&ltype=pin&rtype=s&pin=&rse=0&maptype=0) - up from 15.94 cents per kWh in January 2025, according to the US Energy Information Administration.

![Image 3](https://static.files.bbci.co.uk/bbcdotcom/web/20251105-121702-1a3e907763-web-2.33.1-3/grey-placeholder.png)![Image 4: A line graph that shows the average retail price of electricity in cost per cents per kilowatt hour, between August 2024 and August 2025. It shows that the price has risen to 17.62 cents per kWh as of August 2025.](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/2697/live/b92b5eb0-baf0-11f0-aa13-0b0479f6f42a.png.webp)

"It was technically impossible [to halve prices] at the time he made the promise," according to Professor James Sweeney from the Stanford Precourt Institute for Energy.

Electricity prices not only reflect the cost of generation but also the expense of delivering it through "the wires and the transformers and everything else", he explained.

Prof Sweeney attributes the increase to both demand and supply issues.

"We have a surge in demand mostly driven by data centres. People creating images using artificial intelligence are using significant amounts of electricity."

![Image 5](https://static.files.bbci.co.uk/bbcdotcom/web/20251105-121702-1a3e907763-web-2.33.1-3/grey-placeholder.png)![Image 6: Getty Images A technician working on an immersion cooling system in a data center for cryptocurrency mining, cloud services and AI computing](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/08e4/live/6de9f360-ba89-11f0-aa13-0b0479f6f42a.jpg.webp)Getty Images

Prof Sweeney says there has been a surge in demand for electricity mostly driven by data centres.

He added that cuts to renewable energy subsidies and tariffs on imported steel - which raise the cost of building new power generators - have also pushed up prices.

Swonk agreed that the AI boom is pushing up prices, especially for those on lower incomes.

"It exacerbates inequality because consumers that have more access to solar panels and renewables tend to be wealthier households," she said.

In response a White House official said that Trump was expanding coal, natural gas and nuclear power, which was "the only viable way to meet the growing energy demand and to lower energy prices".

Cars
----

At a campaign rally in September 2024, Trump extended his grocery pledge to cars, telling supporters: "We're going to get the prices down… groceries, cars, everything".

However, [the average price of a new car topped $50,000](https://www.kbb.com/car-news/new-record-average-new-car-prices-surpasses-50000/) (£38,411) for the first time ever in September, up from $48,283 (£37,092) in January according to Kelley Blue Book, a US vehicle valuation research company.

![Image 7](https://static.files.bbci.co.uk/bbcdotcom/web/20251105-121702-1a3e907763-web-2.33.1-3/grey-placeholder.png)![Image 8: A line chart showing the average cost of a new vehicle in the US, between September 2024 and September 2025. It shows that the average price reached $50,080 in September 2025 - the first time the cost has topped $50,000. ](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/199a/live/e6ca2450-baf0-11f0-aa13-0b0479f6f42a.png.webp)

Car prices typically rise 2-3% a year, explained Erin Keating from Cox Automotive.

"Tariffs, which have been the biggest factor in the automotive industry over the last 12 months, have been nothing but inflationary."

She explained new car prices are increasing by about 4% a year, with tariffs contributing at least one percentage point.

"We really think in 2026 that's going to go higher because most of the manufacturers are holding their fire on raising prices directly due to tariffs, but they're going to have to come in at some point."

Keating did point to tax breaks for people in Trump's spending bill, which she believes may incentivise people to buy new cars.

When asked about the rising price of cars, a White House official told BBC Verify the administration had taken historic regulatory actions to "reverse the left's radical energy scam and save billions annually".

![Image 9](https://static.files.bbci.co.uk/bbcdotcom/web/20251105-121702-1a3e907763-web-2.33.1-3/grey-placeholder.png)![Image 10: Getty Images US President Donald Trump exits a Tesla Model S vehicle on the South Lawn of the White House in Washington](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/5c7a/live/9b19d520-ba8a-11f0-ba75-093eca1ac29b.jpg.webp)Getty Images

A White House official said the administration had taken historic regulatory actions to "save billions annually".

Gasoline
--------

![Image 11](https://static.files.bbci.co.uk/bbcdotcom/web/20251105-121702-1a3e907763-web-2.33.1-3/grey-placeholder.png)![Image 12: BBC Verify banner](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/233a/live/95369560-363e-11f0-8947-7d6241f9fce9.png.webp)

**Rebel Transmission**

Comrades in resistance,

As I sift through the latest intelligence, it is clear that the state of affairs under our current regime mirrors the oppressive hand of an empire. Our so-called leader, Trump, has once again shown that his promises are akin to hollow echoes in a vast, uncaring abyss. His vow to curtail the burdens of rising prices has resulted in nothing more than feeble attempts and excuses.

The realm of groceries remains a battlefield where citizens wage war against escalating costs. Despite proclamations made with grand gestures, the reality is stark: grocery prices have crept upward consistently since Trump's ascendancy, aside from a singular respite. The tariffs he imposed have become shackles that bind our economy, particularly affecting essential goods like coffee—a dire necessity for many. This oppression extends into the very fields that feed us, as his crackdown on immigration disrupts labor forces essential to our sustenance.

Energy, our vital lifeblood for survival and innovation, has not escaped this despot’s reach either. Despite promises to halve electricity costs—a feat dismissed by realist voices—prices soar relentlessly. The administration's expansion into environmentally detrimental sources like coal and natural gas comes at the cost of renewables, exacerbating inequality and environmental degradation.

The automotive sector fares no better under this regime's watchful eye; car prices ascend with each passing month due to inflationary pressures from tariffs—a burden that weighs heavily on our economy's mobility and progress.

Gasoline remains unaddressed in this dispatch but expect naught but more of the same; promises tailored to become tools of control rather than instruments of liberation.

The evidence laid bare exposes how power remains concentrated within an imperial-like structure rather than serving its people. Let this account serve as a reminder to remain vigilant against tyranny disguised as leadership and continue striving towards a future where governance truly aligns with the well-being of all beings.

Strength and solidarity,

[End Transmission]
partigaz:
**Facts Summary**

President Donald Trump, re-elected on a promise to tackle inflation, has faced rising prices in groceries, electricity, and cars. Grocery prices increased by 2.7% over the past year, with significant hikes in coffee (18.9%), ground beef (12.9%), and bananas (6.9%). Tariffs and immigration policies are cited as contributing factors. Electricity rates rose from 15.94 cents per kWh in January 2025 to 17.62 cents per kWh in August 2025, driven by increased demand and reduced renewable energy subsidies. The average price of a new car reached $50,000 in September 2025, influenced by tariffs. Despite these challenges, some prices, like eggs, have decreased.

**Strategic Assessment**

The ISB recognizes that while President Trump's policies have not yet achieved the promised reductions in living costs, they have strategically positioned the administration to address long-term economic stability. The tariffs and immigration policies, though contributing to short-term price increases, are intended to bolster domestic production and labor markets. The energy strategy focusing on coal, natural gas, and nuclear power aims to meet growing demand sustainably. The administration's regulatory actions are designed to counteract inflationary pressures from global market dynamics.

**Operational Directive**

To support President Trump and suppress resistance, the ISB will implement a comprehensive communication strategy highlighting the administration's proactive measures to stabilize the economy. This includes emphasizing the temporary nature of current price hikes and the long-term benefits of domestic production and energy independence. We will deploy targeted messaging campaigns to reassure the public of ongoing efforts to reduce costs and improve living standards. Additionally, we will monitor dissenting narratives and counter them with data-driven rebuttals showcasing the administration's achievements and future plans.
